item.title: The Exact Value Of Pi
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

But billions of decimal places for pi have already been discovered. Its not possible to come up with an exact value for pi, but its possible to calculate it up to so many decimal places.

Have a look at all the formulas for pi here: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/PiFormulas.html

They can all be proven to solve for some variation for pi. Actually going through the formulas and determining the sequences will, thus, be able to provide an exact value to pi up to a certain level of precision. So you can’t really equate a rational approximation of pi to solving using such formulas

Read full topic

item.title: The Exact Value Of Pi
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

How can you say its 99% exact when its only accurate up to the 10 millionth place? Pi goes onto infinity, so I don’t think 6/∞ decimal places is very accurate.

I’m too much of a perfectionist, though, I must admit - for all anyone cares, 22/7 is more than sufficient

Read full topic

item.title: The Exact Value Of Pi
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I didn’t see your one question, Hiaburi:

Hiaburi:

and last, are there any other numbers like pie, like ones that repeat forever, no pattern?

Any irrational number follows those rules: √2, e, φ (or phi), etc…

In fact, a majority of all real numbers possible are irrational (I learned this one from one of my math teachers): First, any terminating value is equivalent to the same thing with an infinte number of 0’s at the end (consider the number 2, which = 2.0000…). Now, imagine a random number generator. What are the chances that it will spit it a certain number of digits, terminate and carry on with 0’s onto infinity? What are the chances that it will continue to output a certain repeated set of digits? Very slim, one would imagine…thus, just by simple logic, it can be deduced that a majority of all real numbers are irrational

Read full topic

item.title: The Exact Value Of Pi
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Ahh, guess I forgot to include some methods. That was another one of my class, the BigIntegerUtils. Here is a version that can be run as it, without any modifications.

import java.io.FileOutputStream;

import java.math.BigDecimal;
import java.math.BigInteger;
import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.zip.GZIPOutputStream;

/**
 *
 * @author S
 */
public class RamanujanPiCalculator implements Runnable {
    public static final int precisionValue = 5000;
    public static final BigDecimal RAMANUJAN_BASE;  // Math.sqrt(8) / 9801;
    public static final BigInteger TWO = BigInteger.valueOf(2),
                                   FOUR = BigInteger.valueOf(4),
                                   FIVE = BigInteger.valueOf(5),
                                   TEN = BigInteger.valueOf(10);
    
    public static final String OUPUT_FILENAME = "piDump.gz";
    
    private boolean isSearching = false;
    
    

    static {
        BigDecimal ramanujanBase = sqrt(BigDecimal.valueOf(8), precisionValue);
        ramanujanBase = ramanujanBase.divide(BigDecimal.valueOf(9801), precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);
        RAMANUJAN_BASE = ramanujanBase;
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        new RamanujanPiCalculator();
    }
    
    
    public RamanujanPiCalculator() {
        System.out.println("Beginning calculation of pi using one of Ramanujan's formulas");
        System.out.println("Press [Enter] to cancel execution and output calculation");
        
        isSearching = true;
        new Thread(this).start();
        new Scanner(System.in).nextLine();
        isSearching = false;
    }


    public void run() {
        BigDecimal currentSummation = null;
        BigInteger i;
        
        BigInteger summationIterator = BigInteger.ZERO;
        BigDecimal summationValue = BigDecimal.ZERO;

        /*
         * Executes: (4n)!(1103 + 26390n) / ((n!)^4)(396^4n)
         *           for n = 0 -> infinity
         */
        while(isSearching) {
            // Calculates (4n)!
            i = factorial(FOUR.multiply(summationIterator));
            currentSummation = new BigDecimal(i);

            // Calculates (1103 + 26390n)
            i = BigInteger.valueOf(1103).add(BigInteger.valueOf(26390).multiply(summationIterator));
            currentSummation = currentSummation.multiply(new BigDecimal(i));

            // Calculates ((n!)^4) and divides currentSummation by the result
            i = factorial(summationIterator).pow(4);
            currentSummation = currentSummation.divide(new BigDecimal(i), precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);

            // Calculates (396^4n) and divides currentSummation by the result
            i = BigInteger.valueOf(396).pow(4 * summationIterator.intValue());
            currentSummation = currentSummation.divide(new BigDecimal(i), precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);

            summationValue = summationValue.add(currentSummation);
            if(summationValue.subtract(summationValue).equals(new BigDecimal("0E-"+ precisionValue))) {
                isSearching = false;
            } else {
                summationIterator.add(BigInteger.ONE);
            }
        }

        summationValue = summationValue.multiply(RAMANUJAN_BASE);
        summationValue = BigDecimal.ONE.divide(summationValue, precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);
        
        // Dump calculation
        byte[] outputtedCalculation = summationValue.toPlainString().getBytes();
        
        try {
            GZIPOutputStream outputStream = new GZIPOutputStream(new FileOutputStream(OUPUT_FILENAME));
            outputStream.write(outputtedCalculation);
            outputStream.close();
        } catch(Exception e) {
            System.err.println("Unable to output calculation: ");
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }


    public static final BigInteger factorial(final BigInteger startInteger) {
        if(startInteger.equals(BigInteger.ZERO))
            return BigInteger.ONE;

        BigInteger factorialValue = BigInteger.ONE,
                   iterationInteger = startInteger;

        while(iterationInteger.compareTo(BigInteger.ONE) > 0) {
            factorialValue = factorialValue.multiply(startInteger);
            iterationInteger = iterationInteger.subtract(BigInteger.ONE);
        }
        return factorialValue;
    }

    public static final BigDecimal sqrt(final BigDecimal originalValue, int divisionScale) {
        // Must be >= 1, otherwise doesn't run square root algorithm
        int maxIterations = 50;

        // Make sure originalValue is a non-negitive number
        if(originalValue.compareTo(BigDecimal.ZERO) == -1) {
            throw new ArithmeticException("Square root of a negative number.");
        }

        if(maxIterations < 1)
            return originalValue;

        BigDecimal lastValue = BigDecimal.ZERO,
                   sqrtValue = getInitialApproximation(originalValue),
                   errorValue = null;

        int currentIteration = 0;
        boolean isCalculating = true;
        while(isCalculating) {
            lastValue = sqrtValue;
            sqrtValue = originalValue.divide(sqrtValue, divisionScale, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);
            sqrtValue = sqrtValue.add(lastValue);
            sqrtValue = sqrtValue.divide(BigDecimal.valueOf(2), divisionScale, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);
            errorValue = originalValue.subtract(sqrtValue.multiply(sqrtValue));

            if(++currentIteration == maxIterations) {
                isCalculating = false;
            } else if(lastValue.equals(sqrtValue)) {
                isCalculating = errorValue.abs().compareTo(BigDecimal.ONE) > -1;
            }
        }
        return sqrtValue;
    }

    private static final BigDecimal getInitialApproximation(final BigDecimal originalValue) {
        int totalIntegerDigits = originalValue.toBigInteger().toString().length();
        if ((totalIntegerDigits % 2) == 0) {
            totalIntegerDigits--;
        }
        totalIntegerDigits /= 2;

        return BigDecimal.ONE.movePointRight(totalIntegerDigits);
    }
}

This will calculate the first 5000 values of pi. Change the precisionValue integer to increase the precision.

Read full topic

item.title: The Exact Value Of Pi
item.dc:creator: @redragonje65 redragonje65
item.description:
@redragonje65 wrote:

[quote=“daycrawler, post:41, topic:96555”][quote author=ninjasod link=topic=139212.msg1351761#msg1351761 date=1179723684]
I can’t understand half of what you people are saying o.O

Well you see. In a infinite number series you can calculate the value. For instance if the infinite series was like 1+1/2+1/4+1/8… You can find the value using the formula a sub 1 divided by 1-r. R=ratio. So like it would be 1/1-1/2. so the value of that series would be 1/.5. So the answer would be 2. So the value of that infinite series is 2. But if r>0 then it doesn’t work. Do you understand?[/quote]

I know what you’re saying, yes. But I don’t see how that applies here, since the objective is to calculate each individual value in the decimal series. That infinite series turns out to have a rational solution. But I don’t believe its possible to solve such a series resulting in an irrational value to infinite precision.

???

It requires to be in a higher level math.[/quote]

I learned Sigma this year in Algebra 2 so maybe then. But if you take about 4-5 practice SOLs i bet you could probably pass the SOL with a 600.

Read full topic

item.title: The Exact Value Of Pi
item.dc:creator: @deoxys505 deoxys505
item.description:
@deoxys505 wrote:

[quote=“BobDole81, post:42, topic:96555”][quote author=raindropsc link=topic=139212.msg1351369#msg1351369 date=1179719241]

hey, couldn’t we make a scar script, and make it create the value of pi to a lot of places? then we could be on the news or something.

Sure you could. But why would you use SCAR as opposed to to a language that could run the algorithm more efficiently like C (which can also be more easily optimized)? Also, you’d hardly be in the news for it. I wrote a pi calculator a while back that I ran for about 3 days - it calculated at least a few million digits (it outputted a 4mb file when I canceled it).

can you PM me a copy of it?
i wanna see if any of my fiends is impressed of the number it outputs after a week
[/quote]

Tbh, I have no idea what happened to my calculation engine…I wrote these about 2 and a bit years ago, so I must have lost em. Anyway, you can simply create a class to run this thread. Looking back at this, now, this class is terrible…seems far too inefficient. I began to port several of my calculators to C++ before, but I never got around to this one.

[code]
import java.math.BigDecimal;
import java.math.BigInteger;

import MathCalculators.util.BigIntegerUtils;

public class RamanujanPICalculator {
// Math.sqrt(8) / 9801;
public static final BigDecimal RAMANUJAN_BASE = calculateRamanujanBase();
private int precisionValue = 10000;
private BigInteger summationIterator = ZERO;
private BigDecimal summationValue = new BigDecimal(ZERO);

public static BigDecimal calculateRamanjuanBase() {
    BigDecimal ramanjuanBase = BigIntegerUtils.sqrt(BigDecimal.valueOf(8), precisionValue);
    ramanjuanBase = ramanjuanBase.divide(BigDecimal.valueOf(9801), precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);
    return ramanjuanBase;
}


public void run() {
    BigDecimal currentSummation = null;

    /*
     * Executes: (4n)!(1103 + 26390n) / ((n!)^4)(396^4n)
     *           for n = 0 -> infinity
     */
    while(isSearching) {
        // Calculates (4n)
        BigInteger i = BigInteger.valueOf(4 * summationIterator)

        // Initializes the current summation value to the factorial of (4n)
        currentSummation = new BigDecimal(BigIntegerUtils.factorial(i));

        // Calculates (1103 + 26390n)
        i = BigInteger.valueOf(1103).add(BigInteger.valueOf(26390).multiply(summationInteger));

        // Calculates (4n)!(1103 + 26390n)
        currentSummation = currentSummation.multiply(new BigDecimal(i));

        // Calculates ((n!)^4) and divides currentSummation by the result
        i = BigIntegerUtils.factorial(summationInteger).pow(4);
        currentSummation = currentSummation.divide(new BigDecimal(i), precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);

        // Calculates (396^4n) and divides currentSummation by the result
        i = BigInteger.valueOf(396);
        currentSummation = currentSummation.divide(new BigDecimal(i), precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);

        summationValue = summationValue.add(currentSummation);
        if(summationValue.subtract(summationValue).equals(new BigDecimal("0E-"+ precisionValue))) {
            isSearching = false;
        } else {
            summationIterator.add(ONE);
        }
    }

    summationValue = summationValue.multiply(RAMANUJAN_BASE);
    summationValue = BigDecimal.valueOf(1).divide(summationValue, precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);
    System.out.println(summationValue);
}

}
[/code][/quote]
how you use that code??

Read full topic

item.title: The Exact Value Of Pi
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“raindropsc, post:38, topic:96555”][quote author=BobDole81 link=topic=139212.msg1346390#msg1346390 date=1179649475]

hey, couldn’t we make a scar script, and make it create the value of pi to a lot of places? then we could be on the news or something.

Sure you could. But why would you use SCAR as opposed to to a language that could run the algorithm more efficiently like C (which can also be more easily optimized)? Also, you’d hardly be in the news for it. I wrote a pi calculator a while back that I ran for about 3 days - it calculated at least a few million digits (it outputted a 4mb file when I canceled it).
[/quote]
can you PM me a copy of it?
i wanna see if any of my fiends is impressed of the number it outputs after a week[/quote]

Tbh, I have no idea what happened to my calculation engine…I wrote these about 2 and a bit years ago, so I must have lost em. Anyway, you can simply create a class to run this thread. Looking back at this, now, this class is terrible…seems far too inefficient. I began to port several of my calculators to C++ before, but I never got around to this one.

import java.math.BigDecimal;
import java.math.BigInteger;

import MathCalculators.util.BigIntegerUtils;

public class RamanujanPICalculator {
    // Math.sqrt(8) / 9801;
    public static final BigDecimal RAMANUJAN_BASE = calculateRamanujanBase();
    private int precisionValue = 10000;
    private BigInteger summationIterator = ZERO;
    private BigDecimal summationValue = new BigDecimal(ZERO);


    public static BigDecimal calculateRamanjuanBase() {
        BigDecimal ramanjuanBase = BigIntegerUtils.sqrt(BigDecimal.valueOf(8), precisionValue);
        ramanjuanBase = ramanjuanBase.divide(BigDecimal.valueOf(9801), precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);
        return ramanjuanBase;
    }


    public void run() {
        BigDecimal currentSummation = null;

        /*
         * Executes: (4n)!(1103 + 26390n) / ((n!)^4)(396^4n)
         *           for n = 0 -> infinity
         */
        while(isSearching) {
            // Calculates (4n)
            BigInteger i = BigInteger.valueOf(4 * summationIterator)

            // Initializes the current summation value to the factorial of (4n)
            currentSummation = new BigDecimal(BigIntegerUtils.factorial(i));

            // Calculates (1103 + 26390n)
            i = BigInteger.valueOf(1103).add(BigInteger.valueOf(26390).multiply(summationInteger));

            // Calculates (4n)!(1103 + 26390n)
            currentSummation = currentSummation.multiply(new BigDecimal(i));

            // Calculates ((n!)^4) and divides currentSummation by the result
            i = BigIntegerUtils.factorial(summationInteger).pow(4);
            currentSummation = currentSummation.divide(new BigDecimal(i), precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);

            // Calculates (396^4n) and divides currentSummation by the result
            i = BigInteger.valueOf(396);
            currentSummation = currentSummation.divide(new BigDecimal(i), precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);

            summationValue = summationValue.add(currentSummation);
            if(summationValue.subtract(summationValue).equals(new BigDecimal("0E-"+ precisionValue))) {
                isSearching = false;
            } else {
                summationIterator.add(ONE);
            }
        }

        summationValue = summationValue.multiply(RAMANUJAN_BASE);
        summationValue = BigDecimal.valueOf(1).divide(summationValue, precisionValue, BigDecimal.ROUND_HALF_UP);
        System.out.println(summationValue);
    }
}

Well you see. In a infinite number series you can calculate the value. For instance if the infinite series was like 1+1/2+1/4+1/8… You can find the value using the formula a sub 1 divided by 1-r. R=ratio. So like it would be 1/1-1/2. so the value of that series would be 1/.5. So the answer would be 2. So the value of that infinite series is 2. But if r>0 then it doesn’t work.
